title: The City’s massive size is a blessing, not a curse, say academics
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Aug 19, 2015, 10:50 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 40 mins The City’s massive size is a blessing, not a curse, say academics By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 15 minutes ago 28.00 0.00 
Britain’s finance sector “defied gravity” to come through the financial crisis in surprisingly good shape because it is so big and diverse, boffins have found 
Britain’s banks and finance firms performed surprisingly well in the credit crunch and its aftermath because the industry is enormous, with good links to countries all around the world, according to analysis from leading academics. 
Despite the conventional view that the City of London (LSE: CIN.L - news ) and its banks became too big and too complex, the paper, written by Professor Dariusz Wójcik at the University of Oxford and Dr Daniel Haberley at the University of Sussex, argues that the size and scope of the UK finance sector made it more resilient than smaller rivals. 
“While the international position of British banks has clearly benefitted from the UK’s location outside of the Eurozone, their foreign currency balance sheets were nevertheless extremely stretched on the eve of the crisis, and seem to have defied gravity in its wake,” the academics argue in their paper, titled “Fragile renegades: Offshore banking centres in the global financial crisis.” 
“Our results suggest that this surprising resilience may stem from the uniquely diversified global connections of the City, which has been able to pivot, in the wake of the crisis, away from Europe towards more robust American and Asian sources of funding.” 
By contrast, countries which had large finance sectors as a proportion of their GDP but which were not diversified such as Ireland , Cyprus and Iceland have suffered more. 
Eurozone economies also performed poorly, the academics found, in part because they have no direct control over their own currency, effectively leaving them just as exposed as if all their domestic business were carried out in a foreign currency. 
However, financial centres such as Singapore joined Britain in performing strongly, not because they were as diversified as the City of London, but because their governments have enormous resources at hand to back the finance sector, thanks to large budget surpluses and substantial foreign currency reserves. 
However, Professor Wójcik and Dr Haberley also note that it is not clear the regulatory reforms since the credit crunch have made the British finance sector safer. They argue that “all national banking systems, in the event of a crisis, behave as though they were de facto state-owned by their home government” and that "the greatest threat to national solvency is likely the private debt of these banks”.
